[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/lib.rs] [Function: zip_metadata()] [Compression bomb DoS] Can an attacker craft malicious metadata that, when passed to zip_metadata() with repetitive patterns, produces extremely large compressed output causing memory exhaustion during serialization and deployment? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/lib.rs] [Function: unzip_metadata()] [Decompression bomb DoS] Can malicious compressed metadata bypass size limits during unzip_metadata() decompression, causing memory exhaustion or OOM crashes when validators process package metadata? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/lib.rs] [Function: unzip_metadata()] [Integer overflow] Does unzip_metadata() validate the decompressed size before allocation, or can crafted gzip headers with massive size claims cause integer overflow leading to buffer overflow or incorrect memory allocation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/lib.rs] [Function: zip_metadata_str()] [UTF-8 validation bypass] Can invalid UTF-8 sequences in string metadata bypass validation during zip_metadata_str() encoding, leading to state corruption when metadata is later parsed on-chain? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/lib.rs] [Function: unzip_metadata_str()] [UTF-8 parsing vulnerability] Does unzip_metadata_str() properly validate UTF-8 after decompression, or can attackers inject malformed UTF-8 sequences that cause panics or undefined behavior in downstream string processing? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/lib.rs] [Function: unzip_metadata()] [Arbitrary resource consumption] Can repeatedly calling unzip_metadata() with crafted compression ratios (e.g., 1000:1) exhaust system resources during package verification, causing validator nodes to crash or slow down? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/lib.rs] [Function: zip_metadata()] [Compression level exploit] Does the use of Compression::best() in zip_metadata() create unnecessary CPU consumption during package builds, allowing attackers to slow down framework deployments or governance proposals? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/lib.rs] [Function: unzip_metadata()] [Read amplification attack] Can attackers craft gzip streams that cause read_to_end() in unzip_metadata() to perform excessive I/O operations, potentially causing disk exhaustion or validator slowdowns? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/lib.rs] [Function: path_in_crate()] [Path traversal] Can relative path arguments containing '../' sequences in path_in_crate() escape the CARGO_MANIFEST_DIR boundary, allowing attackers to read arbitrary files from the validator filesystem? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/lib.rs] [Function: path_in_crate()] [Symlink exploitation] Does path_in_crate() resolve symbolic links, allowing attackers to craft package paths that point outside the intended crate directory through symlink attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/lib.rs] [Function: path_relative_to_crate()] [Canonicalization bypass] Can path_relative_to_crate() fail to properly canonicalize paths with '.', '..', or symlinks, leading to incorrect relative paths that bypass security checks in package verification? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/lib.rs] [Function: path_in_crate()] [TOCTOU race condition] Is there a time-of-check-time-of-use vulnerability in path_in_crate() where a path is validated but then modified before use, allowing attackers to swap files during framework builds? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/lib.rs] [Function: path_relative_to_crate()] [Panic on invalid paths] Does path_relative_to_crate() using unwrap_or() properly handle all edge cases, or can crafted paths cause panics during package metadata generation leading to build failures? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/lib.rs] [Function: path_in_crate()] [Environment variable injection] Can CARGO_MANIFEST_DIR environment variable be manipulated in production deployments to point path_in_crate() to attacker-controlled directories during package verification? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/src/lib.rs] [Module: built_package] [Source digest bypass] Can malicious actors craft packages with identical source digests but different bytecode by exploiting compression in zip_metadata(), enabling stealth backdoors in framework upgrades? (Critical)
